description.narrative: Environmental challenges in Bhutan are relatively small due to the history of the country. Nevertheless due to rapid modernization of the Bhutanese society, the pressure to exploitation of natural resources is also increasing. For instance infrastructure a nd hydropower development, poaching and illegal wildlife trade, human- wildlife conflicts, illegal logging, excessive gathering of forest commodities as well as forest fires threaten the valuable and untouched nature of Bhutan. In addition, climate change is already causing major changes in the environment which causes challenges for local people's livelihoods.The establishment of protected areas and national parks and training of forest guards and villagers to prevent poaching and illegal wildlife trade we improve the status of endangered species such as tigers and snow leopards. The promotion of research including camera trapping and GPS tracking increases information about the movement of the species and helps to improve their protection. The development of alternative forms of income such as ecotourism and viewing centers for women, improves the well-being of local people. Local villagers are also supported through development of compensation schemes, in case their cattle has been attacked by wildlife.
